title: Staying Safe: A sociology of how injecting drug users avoid viral infection in the long-term
abstractText:
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality linked to injecting drug use (IDU). Over 60 per cent of IDUs in London are HCV antibody positive, rising to over 75 per cent prevalence among those injecting for at least eight years.

This qualitative study explores the long-term viral avoidance in an environment of high risk. Qualitative life history interviews will be undertaken with 30 long-term IDUs who have not been exposed to hepatitis C alongside interviews with 30 who have been exposed to hepatitis C. In addition, a sub-sample will be followed-up twice over 9-12 months. This study is akin to a 'positive deviance' 'control-case' design which reverses a traditional focus on risk associated with incident cases of infection to concentrate on long-term avoidance of infection in a setting of high transmission risk.

The aim is to understand the social practices of long-term viral avoidance, and how these are shaped through the trajectories of IDUs and their social contexts over time. The findings will inform a new generation of HCV prevention interventions in the UK.
organisation: London Sch of Hygiene and Trop Medicine
